div1.head: Jim to Mon. Paul Rockwell July 8th 1915
div1.p:
We have all been very very busy during the past ten days and in the last few days its been a continuous go. As it stands now I haven’t slept for a couple of days and am now waiting another call this night. If you’ve been following the papers you will know why. The roar has kept up day and night. In spite of the rush we managed to pull off a regular old 4th of July fest. Captain Watt and Noel, the Aviators, were guests and what with our Frenchmen in various sorts of uniforms our board had a many colored appearance. Things were done up in style. Someone had even scared up a piano. We found wine and champagne glasses in the caserne and from the nearest city we had brought paper napkins. An architect in the outfit had make special menues [sic] decorated with our flag. It was a classy affair but somewhat halting in that calls kept coming in and we were forced to be continually going out. Each man did some “stunt” and I remember how well Gunga Din sounded, recited as it was, when the artillery was roaring outside. We had all the 4th of July noise one could wish for and illuminating rockets afforded a quota of fireworks. The Boches evidently didn’t think we had done it up brown for they gave us a short bombardment later in the evening.
The wounds are frightful these days and a good many die before we get them to the surgeons. The only consolation lies in the fact that the Boches are getting it just as badly. The damn swine are using gas and as an extra barbarism they throw petrol jets on the choking soldiers.

It seems that its the Army of the Crown Prince operating against us here. I didn’t know that before. It also turns out that the Germans, as we have found out from prisoners, know an American section is doing the sanitary work for the French in this secteur. Of course they see our cars, but I didn’t know before that they knew that we were an American section. As a matter of fact its quite mixed, with English, French, a Hollander and ourselves. The latest addition is R. J. Cunningham the famous African lion hunter. He’s a fine, old fellow but got poisoned and has been evacuated for awhile.

Marcelle Guerin tells me you and your brother are going to dine Chez elle and that possibly she’ll get Mlle. Du Bouchet to fill in. Seems years since you and I were there and you were late getting back to the Ambulance. Remember? It was the night before I left. The outfit looks very much changed since it pulled out of
the yard that morning with flags flying. Flags! Oh hell. They were pulled off long ago. I’ve gone thru [sic] one car and for the past month have been driving a new one. The few cars that were detached from the fizzle of a tent section and assigned to do our evacuation below the zone have been a lot of bother. Four of the men have quit, two cars have been smashed driving at night and they’ve gone on the bum generally. The outfit wasn’t much good to start with naturally, but there are two or three good men and as soon as they are tried out we may take them on. A good deal of responsibility has been given us — Not even any French automobile section is located as close as we are, — and we have to be very careful who we accept. There are three fellows in the gang now that I wish could be got rid of.

At last things seem to have quieted down here, but believe me the whole works has been raising some intense little action. The Boches on the hill at the end of our street whose trenches are but 1,400 yards off got fresh the other night. Its just a salient that comes in there, unimportant, and as they haven’t been doing anything, nor indulging in any great amount of shooting down with
rifles they’ve been let alone. Why they got so tame that sometimes their sentinels would stand up clear cut against the sky. Well sir, the night of the fifth about 9 P.M. you should have heard the howl they let loose and down they started for town. We couldn’t see very well but it certainly wasn’t very far down before they got it. The report of rifles and sing of the mitrailleuses blended into one continuous whirring clatter and in ten minutes it was over. They got badly shot up. That’s an awful crust on their part but I guess they won’t try it again.
Doesn’t the American action in regard to the war make you tired? Its Mexico all over again. Sort of a make-a- bluff-and-if-its-called-try-another, diplomacy.
You never run across Betty Baldwin of 11 Bis Bvd Debessert do you? I hear from her now and then. Damn nice of the kid to write.
Excuse the dullness of this letter but my brain won’t work at all now.
How are things going with you? Have you received the two letters I sent in by the staff car some time ago?
